{{Lead too short|date=July 2010}} {{Infobox football biography |playername=Keisuke Honda |image=[[File:Keisuke Honda CSKA.jpg|200px]] |fullname=Keisuke Honda |dateofbirth={{birth date and age|1986|6|13|df=y}} |cityofbirth=[[Settsu]] |countryofbirth=[[Japan]] |height={{convert|1.83|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |position=[[Midfielder|Attacking midfielder]] |currentclub=[[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] |clubnumber=7 |youthyears1= |youthclubs1=Settsu FC |youthyears2=1999â2001 |youthclubs2=[[Gamba Osaka]] |youthyears3=2002â2004 |youthclubs3=SeiryÅ High School |years1=2005â2007 |clubs1=[[Nagoya Grampus|Nagoya Grampus Eight]] |caps1=90 |goals1=11 |years2=2008â2009 |clubs2=[[VVV-Venlo]] |caps2=68 |goals2=24 |years3=2009â |clubs3=[[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] |caps3=47 |goals3=13 |nationalyears1=2005 |nationalteam1=[[Japan national under-20 football team|Japan U-20]] |nationalcaps1=1 |nationalgoals1=0 |nationalyears2=2006â2008 |nationalteam2=[[Japan national under-23 football team|Japan U-23]] |nationalcaps2=18 |nationalgoals2=5 |nationalyears3=2008â |nationalteam3=[[Japan national football team|Japan]] |nationalcaps3=31 |nationalgoals3=8 |pcupdate=05:13, 19 November 2011 (UTC) |ntupdate=1 June 2011 }} {{nihongo|'''Keisuke Honda'''|æ¬ç° å­ä½|Honda Keisuke|born 13 June 1986}} is a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[Association football|footballer]] who currently plays for Russian [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] and the [[Japan national football team]]. His current position is as a deep-lying playmaker, but he can equally play as an attacking midfielder or second striker. He is also a very skilled free kick taker scoring one in the [[FIFA World Cup 2010]] in [[South Africa]].
==Club career==
===Early career=== Honda was born in Settsu, Osaka Prefecture. He started playing football for the local club; Settsu FC, he started there when he was in second grade at primary school. He entered Seiryo High School in Ishikawa Prefecture and chose to play for the school. He was one of the best players in the team and the school team advanced to the semi-finals of the All Japan High School Soccer Tournament. This was the first time a school from Ishikawa Prefecture had reached the semi-finals of the competition.<ref>{{cite web|last=Administrator|first=Administrator|title=Kesuke's Early Life|url=http://www.keisukehonda.com/index.php/early-days|accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref>
In 2004 he was selected as a Designated Player for Development by the J-League and JFA.
===Nagoya Grampus Eight=== Because of this status, Honda was able to register as a [[Nagoya Grampus|Nagoya Grampus Eight]] player while he was still eligible to play for his high school. He played one [[J. League Cup]] match for Nagoya while he was still a boy student.
After his graduation, he officially joined Nagoya in 2005. He started the first match of the season and recorded an assist. In 2006, he became a regular in the club.
===VVV-Venlo=== [[File:Keisuke Honda Eredivisie 2.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Honda with [[VVV-Venlo]]]]
[[File:Keisuke Honda Eredivisie 3.jpg||thumb|left|upright|Honda celebrates his goal against FC Groningen at the De Koel stadium on August 22, 2009]] On January 16, 2008, Honda signed a two and half year deal with [[Eredivisie]] side [[VVV-Venlo]]. The team was relegated to the [[Eerste Divisie]], the second division after the 07-08 season and was in the division for the 08-09 season. In the 08-09 season, he scored 16 goals in 36 league appearances to help the team to be promoted to [[Eredivisie]] for the 09-10 season. He became known as 'Keizer Keisuke' (Emperor Keisuke) among the fans of VVV-Venlo.<ref name=uefa/>
===CSKA Moscow=== At the end of December 2009 Honda transferred to the Russian club CSKA Moscow.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vi.nl/Nieuws-item-TS1/174277/CSKA-en-VVV-bereiken-akkoord-over-Honda.htm |title= CSKA en VVV bereiken akkoord over Honda|accessdate=2009-12-30 |date= 2009-12-30 |author=VI.nl|language=Dutch}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Honda signed a 4 year contract.<ref>[http://www.sports.ru/football/61419084.html Ð Ð¾Ð¼Ð°Ð½ ÐÐ°Ð±Ð°ÐµÐ²: Â«Ð£ ÐÑÐ¼Ð±Ð¸Ñ Ð±ÑÐ»Ð¸ Ð±Ð¾Ð»ÐµÐµ Ð¿ÑÐ¸Ð²Ð»ÐµÐºÐ°ÑÐµÐ»ÑÐ½ÑÐµ Ð² ÑÐ¸Ð½Ð°Ð½ÑÐ¾Ð²Ð¾Ð¼ Ð¾ÑÐ½Ð¾ÑÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¸ Ð²Ð°ÑÐ¸Ð°Ð½ÑÑ, ÑÐµÐ¼ Ð¦Ð¡ÐÐÂ»] (Russian)</ref> The transfer fee was undisclosed, but VVV-Venlo was said to be very content with the fee as it almost matched their asking price, it is believed to be in the region of 6 million euros.<ref name=uefa>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=939712.html |title='Emperor Keisuke' joins the Army Men |author= |date=1 January 2010 |work= |publisher=UEFA.com |accessdate=8 July 2010}}</ref>
Honda made his debut for CSKA in the [[UEFA Champions League]]-match against [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/world/169615/gonzalez-wonder-goal-earns-cska-draw-against-sevilla |title= Gonzalez wonder goal earns CSKA draw against Sevilla|accessdate=2010-02-25 |date= 2010-02-25 |author=Bangkok Post}}</ref> In the second leg in Seville, he scored the winning goal through a [[direct free kick]] for CSKA after having set up the first goal for [[TomÃ¡Å¡ Necid]]. This secured a 2â1 (3â2 aggregate) victory to send the club to the quarterfinals, making Honda the first Japanese player to be in the quarterfinals as well as the first to score in the knock-out stages.
Honda scored his first [[Russian Premier League|league]] goal on 12 March 2010, in the home match against [[FC Amkar Perm|Amkar Perm]]. He scored the goal in the third minute of injury time, slotting home a pass from Necid with his left. With the goal, he secured the win for CSKA Moscow.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transfermarkt.de/de/zska-moskauamkar-perm/index/spielbericht_999029.html |title=ZSKA Moskau 1:0 (0:0) Amkar Perm |publisher=Transfermarkt.de |date= |accessdate=2010-06-14}}</ref>
==International career== He was a member of the [[Japan national football team|Japan]] team for [[2005 FIFA World Youth Championship]] and played for U-23 national team, that qualified for [[2008 Summer Olympics]] football tournament finals. He made a full international debut for [[Japan national football team|Japan]] on June 22, 2008 in a FIFA World Cup qualifier against [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]]. On 14 July 2008, he was formally named as one of the midfielders of the Japanese U-23 national football team for the Beijing Olympics football competition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en/Articolo.aspx?ContenutoId=776891 |title= Japan Name Olympic Squad|accessdate=2008-07-17 |date= 2008-07-14 |author=[[Goal.com]]}}</ref> He scored his first goal for senior national team on 27 May 2009 in a friendly match against [[Chile national soccer team|Chile]] at [[Nagai Stadium]] in [[Osaka]].He is given the nickname "Emperor [[Keisuke]]".
===2010 World Cup=== Honda scored [[Japan national football team|Japan]]'s winning goal in their first [[2010 World Cup]] match against [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]], finishing off [[Daisuke Matsui]]'s cross into the top left corner of the net and this was the only goal in the match. His performance in the game gained him the Man of the Match Award from [[FIFA]]. In the final group-stage game against [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]], he scored a free kick in the 17th minute from 30 yards out before turning provider for [[Shinji Okazaki]] after making his way into the penalty area, with a [[Cruyff Turn]] that beat a Denmark player, in the 88th minute to make the score 3â1 to Japan, a performance that earned him the man of the match award once more and Japan qualified for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|second round]] where they were eliminated by [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] after 0â0 a.e.t. and 4â5 at penalties (Honda scored his penalty).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_43/default.stm|title=Denmark 1â3 Japan|date=2010-06-24|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|first=Sam|last=Sheringham|accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> [[Jonathan Wilson (journalist/author)|Jonathan Wilson]] of [[The Guardian]] cited him as a 'false nine': a player superficially employed as a centre forward but moving deeper to pull the opposition defence around the pitch.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/blog/2010/jul/09/world-cup-2010-tactics-the-question|title=The Question: What have been the tactical lessons of World Cup 2010?|date=2010-07-11|first=Jonathan|last=Wilson|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=2010-07-12}}</ref>
===2011 AFC Asian Cup=== Honda was included in the [[2011 AFC Asian Cup]] by coach [[Alberto Zaccheroni]]. In the game against [[Syria national football team|Syria]] he scored a penalty kick making the score 2â1, for [[Japan national football team|Japan]]. He earned player of the match for that game. In the [[semi-finals]] against [[Korea Republic national football team|Korea Republic]], he shot a penalty kick, but was blocked by [[Jung Sung-Ryong]]. But in the penalty shoot outs of that game, he scored. Again he earned player of the match.
Honda was awarded the [[most valuable player]] of the [[2011 AFC Asian Cup]].
==Personal life== Honda's elder brother was also a footballer. Honda's uncle Daizaburo Honda was a canoeist who represented Japan in the [[1964 Summer Olympics|1964 Tokyo Olympics]]. Daizaburo's son and Keisuke's cousin [[Tamon Honda]] participated in three Olympic Games in [[freestyle wrestling]] in 1984, 1988, and 1992 and is now a professional wrestler.<ref>asahi.com [http://www2.asahi.com/olympic2008/column/TKY200807070134.html ä¸äººç«ã¤ãå¤¢ã¸ã®èå° ãµãã«ã¼ã»æ¬ç°å­ä½ãã â å®¶æç©èª -] retrieved on February 13, 2009</ref>
